File which controls how SDL_Config library will be compiled

In order to change behaviour of SDL_Config, you must make changes directly in SDL config cfg.h file, then recompile SDL_Config, and finally recompile your application.  For the list of things that can be tweaked, see below.

Summary
File which controls how SDL_Config library will be compiledIn order to change behaviour of SDL_Config, you must make changes directly in SDL config cfg.h file, then recompile SDL_Config, and finally recompile your application.
Macros
CFG_GCC_STRING_PROBLEMSDefining CFG_GCC_STRING_PROBLEMS may be useful when you’re compiling C programs on GCC/MinGW.
CFG_FloatChange it to double to increase the size of floats that you may use.
CFG_USE_BOOLNative bool support is maintained for people using C++.
CFG_USE_DEFAULT_VALUESIt controls what version of function definitions will be compiled: those with or without default values.
CFG_BUILD_DLLDefines that library will be build as dynamically linked library.
CFG_PROFILE_LIBIf defined, library will generate output to stdout about how much miliseconds it took to Open/Save files.
CFG_USE_MULTIMAPIf defined, you can keep multiple groups with the same name in one file.
CFG_REDEFINE_BOOL_KEYWORDSIf defined, you can change bool keywords.
CFG_DEBUG_LIBIf defined, library will be sending debugging output to stderr.
CFG_ASSERT_NULL_ENABLEDWhen defined, if the pointer to currently selected file equals 0 at any point where it would cause mysterious SEGFAULTS etc.
CFG_LOG_VERY_CRITICAL_ERRORCritical library errors shouldn’t ever happen, so if you encounter one of them, you must be doing sth really weird.

Macros

CFG_GCC_STRING_PROBLEMS

Defining CFG_GCC_STRING_PROBLEMS may be useful when you’re compiling C programs on GCC/MinGW.  If you will run onto linking problems in such a situation, defining it might help.

Unfortunately, I tried it on MinGW 3.5 and it wasn’t linkining properly due to string::substr().

By default, not defined.

CFG_Float

Change it to double to increase the size of floats that you may use.

By default: float

CFG_USE_BOOL

Native bool support is maintained for people using C++.  It is assumed that if you are compiling in C++, you want to use bool, and in this way those defintions are constructed.  However, you may choose to use int instead - just change CFG_USE_BOOL value to 1.

If you want to use SDL_Config from within C code, you must change CFG_USE_BOOL value to 1 before compiling the library.  It can’t be detected automatically what language are you going to use.

There’s also third option for SDL junkies, SDL_bool (for details consult SDL documentation).

If you’re not sure what to use since the bool type might change throughout the developement, consider using CFG_Bool, CFG_True and CFG_False which are defined accordingly to CFG_USE_BOOL value.

Summary

0C++ bool (default)
1int
2SDL_bool

By default, 0.

CFG_USE_DEFAULT_VALUES

It controls what version of function definitions will be compiled: those with or without default values.  Obviously, default values are supported and can be used only in C++, so if you’re compiling with C, undefine CFG_USE_DEFAULT_VALUES before compilation of SDL_Config.  It can’t be detected automatically what language are you going to use.

By default, defined.

CFG_BUILD_DLL

Defines that library will be build as dynamically linked library.  If it’s not defined, static version will be build.

Important note: in order to compile DLL version you also have to define CFG_BUILD_DLL somewhere in the SDL_Config project’s options (ie.  “C/C++ -> Preprocessor -> Preprocessor definitions” in Visual Studio) if you’re not using official SDL_Config project file.

By default, defined.

CFG_PROFILE_LIB

If defined, library will generate output to stdout about how much miliseconds it took to Open/Save files.  Beware that you must call SDL_Init(SDL_INIT_TIMER) before calling any SDL_Config functions and SDL_Quit() at end of program if you are using this functionality (unless you’re doing this already).  It uses SDL’s SDL_GetTicks() timer which usually has a few milisecond precision.

By default, not defined.

CFG_USE_MULTIMAP

If defined, you can keep multiple groups with the same name in one file.  To access them, you have to iterate over all groups, since calling CFG_File::CFG_SelectGroup will give you access only to the first one.

By default, not defined.

CFG_REDEFINE_BOOL_KEYWORDS

If defined, you can change bool keywords.

Can be used by C++ users.  Currently I have no idea how to make them available in plain C, since there’s no equivalent of std::string, and changing type to char array would make it harder to work with it in C++.  So, if you want to change boolean keywords and you’re using C++, uncomment the define and recompile lib.

By default, not defined.

CFG_DEBUG_LIB

If defined, library will be sending debugging output to stderr.

By default, not defined.

CFG_ASSERT_NULL_ENABLED

When defined, if the pointer to currently selected file equals 0 at any point where it would cause mysterious SEGFAULTS etc. this will happen: to sderr.txt will be outputted such an information:

Application which uses SDL_Config library (version: %VERSION) has created
an errorneus situation: pointer to selected file is equal to NULL (0) at
%LINE line of file %FILE, so that function %FUNCTION can't continue.

Also, application will be immediately terminated through calling assembler interrupt 3.

By default, it’s defined but not working.  You have to enable CFG_DEBUG_LIB for it to work.

Note

If __FUNCTION__ macro isn’t supported by your compiler, you may run into errors when compiling library with CFG_ASSERT_NULL_ENABLED.  However, it should be supported by all modern compilers (ie.  GCC, VisualC++).

CFG_LOG_VERY_CRITICAL_ERROR

Critical library errors shouldn’t ever happen, so if you encounter one of them, you must be doing sth really weird.  However, they may also indicate bug in the library, in which case you should mail me.

If CFG_DEBUG_LIB is defined, it is also defined (though you might control it separately).  If defined, you’ll see warning in stderr.txt and CFG_GetError(), otherwise you’ll get it only in CFG_GetError().

List ( id / issued by)

001CFG_ReadBool() - value stored in bool entry doesn’t equals one of correct values
002CFG_Internal_RWfind()
003CFG_GetSelectedGroupName()
004CFG_StartGroupIteration(), CFG_SelectNextGroup, CFG_IsLastGroup, CFG_RemoveSelectedGroup - issued when iteration_direction specified by user does not equals CFG_ITERATE_NORMAL or CFG_ITERATE_REVERSE
int CFG_SelectGroup(CFG_String_Arg group =  CFG_GLOBAL,
CFG_Bool create =  CFG_True)
Selects group with appropriate name in the currently selected file.
